chapterTitle: Financial Statements, Taxes, and Cash Flow

columns.text: This exercise requires us to determine it is possible to pay cash dividends and to compute for the cash flow to creditor.
If a company's net income is negative, it may still be able to pay dividends as long as there is enough cash flow to cover the dividend payments.

Second, we will now compute the cash flow from assets.

Lastly, we will now compute the net new long-term debt by deducting the cash flow to creditors to the interest.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Net New Long-term Debt} &= \text{Interest} - {\text{Cash Flow to Creditors}}\\[5pt] 
&= \text{\$70,000} - {\text{63,000}}\\[5pt] 
&= \underline{\underline{\textbf{\$7,000}}} 
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the net new long-term debt is **$7,000**.
